title: Emergent Publics
abstractText:
This project challenged assumptions about the decline of the public sphere in the face of ‘neo-liberal’ challenges to public institutions, the shift to individualization and transformations of collective solidarities.The value of publicness has come to the fore because of:

  • the modernisation of welfare states and changing forms of governance
  • the development of new forms of transnational public action provoked by environmental, human rights, and trade justice movements
  • new forms of public communication enabled by web based technologies
  • new forms of uncertainty related to environmental risk, securitisation, and financial crisis.

These practical and institutional developments have outstripped the conceptual, empirical and normative resources for explaining and evaluating new modes of public action.

This project developed new cross-disciplinary perspectives on the dynamics of public formation, focussing on different aspects of the emergence of new publics. This included elaborating on processes of mobilising publics, how different objects and events provoke public concern, and how communities of affected interest are mobilised around these concerns; practices of public feeling, exploring the multiple registers through which participation in public action is mobilised, and exploring the reconfiguration of identifications based on solidarity, care, and faith; and the production and circulation of different forms of public knowledge.
